Dear Mr. Skornia:
This fall the November issue of AUDIO-VISUAL INSTRUCTION
will be devoted to educational television. Among several
articles planned is a pro and con treatment of subscrip¬
tion television. The magazine1s editorial committee has
suggested that I contact you in regard to the pro argu¬
ment. Would you be willing to contribute your time and
effort to furnish us with this article,?
We do not yet have a "con" author; we are soliciting
suggestions from Mr. Steele of JCET, but if you have
any suggestions we would like to have them also.
PAUL W. F. WITT
Professor of Education, Teachers
College, Columbia University
National Staff
FLOYDE E. BROOKER
Executive Secretary
ANNA L. HYER
Associate Executive Secretary
FLORENCE IH-CHI FAN
Administrative Assistant
MARY C. WELCH
Administrative Assistant
Our articles usually run around 1500 words, less if they
are illustrated. Can you think of any way to illustrate
an article on this subject—photos or otherwise? The
deadline for November articles is September 1.
As it is now planned the November issue will contain art¬
icles on the following subjects: a round-up of ETV exper¬
iments in public schools throughout the country; a sim¬
ilar round-up on the college level; pros and cons of sub¬
scription television; unsolved problems in ETV (this
will probably be a digest of the findings of DAVI*s
workshop and seminar to be held in August-Sept ember);
TV equipment; building facilities that look to a future
of ETV; and, legal aspects of ETV.
